ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about Russian politics, surveillance, big data, AI, machine learning, causal inference, and the applications to political control.

Coding skills in R and Python; Data analysis skills such as Unsupervised/Supervised Learning + additional coding skills relevant to the final project. Also learned how to read social science papers that involve Big Data techniques.

I developed knowledge about Russian politics, Big Data and machine learning methods, and how these methods are utilized by various political actors in a Russian context. I also learned how to apply machine learning models in R and had the opportunity to conduct a final research project of my choice that applied machine learning methods to data from the Russian political world and glean relevant insights from this analysis.

This course explored concepts in contemporary Russian politics, historical context, and the use of media and data in governments around the world. It helped us to read critically, contextualize all of the discussions, and apply some simple techniques to data ourselves.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the seminar discussions were very good especially with the small class size. Towards the middle of the class, the R workshops were very helpful, but they could have easily been recorded ahead of time, adn we would have had more time to discuss the bigger topics in class.

The strengths of this course were its organization and the instructor. The course was well organized to help students develop the requisite knowledge and skills necessary to complete the final project. The instructor was a gem; Anton was highly invested in his students' learning and always made himself available to assist students with coursework. There were no weaknesses to this course.

Strengths: The readings were well thought-out, with lots of interesting topics of discussion. Two R workshops helped improve my skills in applying new machine learning techniques to data.

Weaknesses: The 2-hour seminar time was often too long in many instances; having part of the seminar time devoted to some lecture component instead of it being mostly discussion-based would alleviate this.
The course was very strong, both organizationally and content-wise. I found it to be one of the better courses I've taken at Yale so far, and it was easily the highlight of my semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: as good as it could be
One of the best practices of this course was the availability of the instructor; Anton readily made himself available for Office Hours so that students would always be able to seek help when needed.
Virtual, weekly office hours were helpful in seeking assistance and answering questions.
This class was well optimized for online learning, relying on both projects and long readings to underpin our learning, which I think is the format that works best.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to anyone who would like to learn more about Russia and a big picture analysis of AI techniques. The class requires somewhat of a techncal background in stats/CS/coding but was never overbearing.

Absolutely; this is one of the best seminars I have taken during my time at Yale. It presents a relatively low-stress opportunity to not just develop a wide range of coding/data analysis skills but also learn how to apply them in the context of social sciences - both in reading/analyzing academic literature as well as conducting one's own research. I cannot think of a better recommendation for a seminar during my time at Yale.

If you are very interested in Russian politics and already have some background in machine learning / big data, then this course would be helpful for you. The course helped improve R skills and offered the opportunity to apply a more rigorous quantitive framework to the social sciences and political science, culminating in a final research assignment. However, if you are not interested or well-versed in either of those areas, then this course is not for you.
I would recommend this class in a heartbeat to anyone interested in international politics, data, or Russian-related issues.

extras.title:
PLSC 455 01
        Big Data and Russian Politics
